output.final_deliverable:
Status: Cannot complete the requested integrated, fully-cited analysis yet — missing source evidence.

What I checked:
- You supplied two merged task nodes that show the research and synthesis steps were "done" (nodes 121699c9... and e6d9e574...), but neither node contains the actual authoritative source lists, summaries, or the collected citations required to support the cross-domain synthesis. The merged data includes the tasks, requirements, and deliverables, but not the concrete source material or extracted evidence (citations, summaries, or claims) needed to satisfy your mandate.

Why I cannot proceed as-is:
- Your mandate requires that every key claim be traceable to at least one authoritative source and that each domain include at least two authoritative sources. The merged items do not contain those sources or their summaries. I must not guess or invent citations; doing so would violate your instruction to use only evidence from searches/visits and the developer instruction to explicitly state missing evidence.

What I propose (pick one or more):
1) I will perform the required evidence-gathering step now and then produce the full integrated report exactly to your specification. This will include: for each of the five domains, gathering at least two authoritative sources (peer-reviewed papers, NIST/IPCC/etc. reports, company whitepapers), extracting 3–6 sentence summaries and 2–4 key points per source, and then producing the cross-domain synthesis with inline citations and an appended references section. Estimated turnaround: 2–3 business days for thorough collection and synthesis; faster (24–48 hours) if you accept a more concise report.

2) If you already have the authoritative sources collected elsewhere, you can provide those source lists (PDFs or URLs). I will use them to produce the integrated report and will ensure every claim is traceable to the provided sources. Estimated turnaround: 24–48 hours after I receive the sources.

3) If you prefer a high-level conceptual synthesis produced from my general knowledge (without traceable, new external citations), I can draft that immediately. Note: this will not meet your requirement that each claim be backed by the collected domain materials and will not include the appended authoritative-source appendix you requested.

Minimum next actions I need from you to proceed:
- Confirm which of the three options above you want (1 = I gather sources and do full report; 2 = you supply sources; 3 = high-level non-cited synthesis).
- If you choose option 1, confirm I may fetch web sources now. If there are specific preferred authorities (e.g., NIST PQC outputs, IPCC AR6, IBM/Google quantum whitepapers, Nature/Science reviews) tell me which to prioritize.

If you choose option 1, I will return a package in the requested format (structured report, executive summary, domain interconnections, conflicts & synergies, scenarios & timelines, prioritized recommendations) and an appendix listing at least two authoritative sources per domain with citations and URLs. I will ensure every substantive claim is traceable to at least one cited source.

If you want me to start immediately, reply: "Proceed to gather sources now" (option 1) or paste/attach your source list (option 2) or request the uncited high-level draft (option 3).
output.action_summary: I cannot produce the requested evidence-backed synthesis because the merged inputs do not include the authoritative sources or extracted evidence required. I must not guess or invent citations. Please choose: (1) allow me to gather the required sources and then I will produce the full report (estimated 2–3 days), (2) provide the authoritative sources you want used and I will synthesize them (24–48 hours), or (3) accept a high-level uncited conceptual draft now (will not meet traceability requirements). Specify which option and any preferred authorities; I will proceed.

9b4edd3e-f430-4489-9a86-bb38500d511a.title: Research and synthesize information across 5 domains: (1) Quantum computing principles and current capabilities, (2) Cryptography and encryption methods, (3) Climate change impact on computing infrastructure, (4) Economic implications of quantum computing adoption, and (5) Ethical considerations of quantum supremacy. Then create a comprehensive analysis explaining how these domains interconnect, what conflicts or synergies exist, and what the future landscape might look like. Each domain must have at least 2 authoritative sources. The synthesis must demonstrate deep understanding of cross-domain relationships.

details.mandate: Research and synthesize information across 5 domains: (1) Quantum computing principles and current capabilities, (2) Cryptography and encryption methods, (3) Climate change impact on computing infrastructure, (4) Economic implications of quantum computing adoption, and (5) Ethical considerations of quantum supremacy. Then create a comprehensive analysis explaining how these domains interconnect, what conflicts or synergies exist, and what the future landscape might look like. Each domain must have at least 2 authoritative sources. The synthesis must demonstrate deep understanding of cross-domain relationships.

merged_results.title: Research and summarize authoritative sources for all five domains

result.title: Research and summarize authoritative sources for all five domains

details.mandate: For each domain below, locate and record at least 2 authoritative sources (peer-reviewed papers, canonical standards/reports, major government/industry whitepapers, or widely-cited textbooks). For each source, capture citation (title, authors, year, URL), a 3–6 sentence summary of the source's main findings or claims, and 2–4 key points that are directly relevant to cross-domain synthesis.

domains.name: Quantum computing principles and current capabilities
domains.requirements: Cover qubit technologies (superconducting, trapped ions, photonics), error correction status, quantum advantage/supremacy demonstrations, current device scales and performance metrics (QPU sizes, fidelity), and notable roadmaps from major labs/companies.

domains.name: Cryptography and encryption methods
domains.requirements: Cover classical public-key cryptography (RSA, ECC), symmetric crypto, post-quantum cryptography (PQC) developments and standards (NIST PQC), timelines and practical migration challenges, and risks posed by quantum algorithms (Shor, Grover).

domains.name: Climate change impact on computing infrastructure
domains.requirements: Cover how climate-driven events (heatwaves, floods, sea-level rise, extreme weather) and long-term temperature increases affect data centers and telecom infrastructure, energy demand and carbon footprint of computing, and adaptation/mitigation strategies (cooling tech, geographic diversification, renewables).

domains.name: Economic implications of quantum computing adoption
domains.requirements: Cover cost dynamics (R&D, deployment, cloud access vs. on-prem), market forecasts, sectoral impacts (finance, pharma, materials, cryptography), labor and skills gaps, and potential macroeconomic effects (productivity, concentration of advantage).

domains.name: Ethical considerations of quantum supremacy
domains.requirements: Cover ethical risks (surveillance, inequality, disruption of secure communications), governance and policy discussions, dual-use concerns, responsible disclosure/transition planning, and frameworks for equitable access and oversight.

details.source_quality_criteria: Prefer peer-reviewed literature, standards bodies (NIST, IEEE), intergovernmental reports (IPCC), government lab/agency reports (NIST, DOE, EU Quantum Flagship), major company technical reports (IBM, Google, Microsoft, IonQ), and high-quality academic reviews. Avoid low-credibility blogs; include credible media only for context.
details.deliverable: A consolidated document listing for each domain: (a) at least 2 authoritative sources with citations and URLs, (b) concise summaries per source, (c) 4–8 domain key takeaways synthesizing across the sources, and (d) an explicit note confirming at least 2 authoritative sources were found for that domain.
details.parent_goal: Research and synthesize information across 5 domains: (1) Quantum computing principles and current capabilities, (2) Cryptography and encryption methods, (3) Climate change impact on computing infrastructure, (4) Economic implications of quantum computing adoption, and (5) Ethical considerations of quantum supremacy. Then create a comprehensive analysis explaining how these domains interconnect, what conflicts or synergies exist, and what the future landscape might look like. Each domain must have at least 2 authoritative sources. The synthesis must demonstrate deep understanding of cross-domain relationships.

merged_results.title: Synthesize cross-domain analysis and produce comprehensive integrated report

result.title: Synthesize cross-domain analysis and produce comprehensive integrated report

details.prerequisite: Use the domain summaries and source lists produced by the research step as primary inputs.
details.mandate: Produce a comprehensive analysis that interconnects the five domains. The analysis must:
tasks: 1) Explain how advances in quantum computing (domain 1) specifically interact with cryptography (domain 2), including timelines for practical threats and transitional mitigation (PQC) strategies, citing sources from both domains.

2) Analyze how climate change impacts on computing infrastructure (domain 3) affect both the deployment choices and geographic distribution of quantum computing resources and cryptographic key management (e.g., data center relocations, continuity planning).

3) Assess economic implications (domain 4) in light of technological capabilities and climate constraints: costs of resilient/green quantum infrastructure, market winners/losers, investment priorities, and workforce needs.

4) Evaluate ethical issues (domain 5) that arise from the combined technical, cryptographic, economic, and climate considerations — e.g., equity of access, concentration of power, national security, and environmental justice concerns.

5) Identify conflicts and synergies across domains (e.g., quantum acceleration vs. PQC costs; centralized quantum hubs vs. climate-vulnerable locations; green energy requirements vs. high-power quantum facilities) with concrete examples and citations.

6) Propose 3–5 plausible future scenarios (short: 3–5 years, medium: 5–12 years, long: 12–25 years) describing possible landscapes considering technology, policy, economy, and climate; for each scenario provide implications and recommended actions for policymakers, industry, and researchers.

7) Provide prioritized recommendations (technical, policy, and ethical) to maximize benefits and reduce harms, including timelines for PQC migration, resilient infrastructure planning, equitable access policies, and research funding priorities.

8) Ensure traceability: every key claim in the synthesis must be backed by at least one source from the collected domain materials; list relevant citations inline or in an appended references section.
details.format: Structured report with executive summary, domain interconnections, conflicts & synergies, scenarios & timelines, recommendations, and references. Include an appendix showing the two-or-more authoritative sources per domain.
details.parent_goal: Research and synthesize information across 5 domains: (1) Quantum computing principles and current capabilities, (2) Cryptography and encryption methods, (3) Climate change impact on computing infrastructure, (4) Economic implications of quantum computing adoption, and (5) Ethical considerations of quantum supremacy. Then create a comprehensive analysis explaining how these domains interconnect, what conflicts or synergies exist, and what the future landscape might look like. Each domain must have at least 2 authoritative sources. The synthesis must demonstrate deep understanding of cross-domain relationships.
